subject: Hey Dan!
Received: by <some IP address> with HTTP; Fri, 9 May 2014 17:27:14 -0700 (PDT)
X-Received: by <some other IP address> with SMTP id <some other random string>; Fri, 09 May 2014 17:27:34 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Hey Dan!
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="<no idea what this means>"
message-headers: <basically all of these same headers but in [[key, value], [key, value]] format>
body-plain:
This is a test message. Its *main* purpose is to to provide some **good
Mailgun data** that can be used as a template for seeding the dev database
with many messages. Its *secondary* purpose is just to verify that using
Markdown to format e-mails works all right.

Here are those same purposes in the form of a list:

1. To provide good Mailgun data
2. To test Markdown formatting

And here is an excerpt from what I've written so far:

> This is a test message. Its *main* purpose
> is to to provide some **good Mailgun data**

Keep up the good work on [PublicInbox](http://www.publicinbox.net/)! Really
impressive stuff.

Oh, I almost forget. Remember to strip out `<script>` tags and other
potential nastiness if you ever want to display the raw HTML of e-mail
messages.

In closing, here is some JavaScript code:

    function reverseString(string) {
      var reversed = '';
      for (var i = 0; i < string.length; ++i) {
        reversed += string[string.length - 1 - 1];
      }
      return reversed;
    }

Can you spot the bug? Just kidding! OK, you take care now.

    }

Can you spot the bug? Just kidding! OK, you take care now.
